page_analysis.text_content:
Basements & Excavated features

Floor area regulations are intended to address the building mass and the appearance of the streetscape. Therefore, if basement area is below grade and does not contribute to the apparent mass of a building, that area, even if it is habitable, need not be included in the total floor area.

Code sections
Page 40
18.12.090 (a, b, & c)
Page 41
18.12.090 (c)
Page 43
18.12.090 (c) (1)
Page 44
18.12.090 (c) (2)

Basement standards

• May not be located in special flood hazard areas.
• May not extend beyond building footprint.
• May not encroach into required yards, except where main dwelling is permitted to extend into rear yard.

FAR
Basements (even habitable ones) do not count as floor area if first floor is no more than 3' above grade.

Fig 35 Basement & grade

Excavated features

There are two types of excavated features:
• Light wells and stairwells
• Below-grade patios

FAR
Excavation will not affect grade or measurement of floor area if standards are met (see pages 42 and 43).

Fig 36 Excavated feature & grade

A: distance between top of first floor and grade if excavation meets the size/dimensional limits described in Figs 39-40 on pp. 42-43.

B: distance between top of first floor and grade if excavated features exceed the size/dimensional limits described in Figs 39-40 on pp. 42-43.

Top of first floor

Grade if excavated features meet standards described in Figs 39-40 on pp. 42-43.

Grade if excavated features exceed standards described in Figs 39-40 on pp. 42-43.

visual_elements.description: A cross-sectional diagram showing a building with basement and excavated feature areas. The diagram labels 'Basement' and 'Excavated feature' areas below the 'Top of first floor'. Two vertical measurements labeled 'A' and 'B' indicate distances between the top of the first floor and grade under different conditions. 'A' corresponds to excavation meeting size/dimensional limits, 'B' corresponds to excavation exceeding those limits. The diagram also shows two different 'Grade' lines depending on whether excavated features meet or exceed standards described in Figs 39-40 on pages 42-43.
A patterned graphic representing basement and grade area, consisting of a hatched pattern forming a stepped shape.

technical_specifications.parameter: First floor height above grade for basement floor area exclusion

additional_notes: Page number 40 is printed at bottom left corner.
The FAR (Floor Area Ratio) notes are highlighted in grey boxes.
References to figures 35 and 36 are italicized below respective diagrams.
References to pages 42 and 43 are made multiple times for detailed standards.
No handwritten annotations or stamps detected.

qualifiers.text: May not be located in special flood hazard areas.
May not extend beyond building footprint.
May not encroach into required yards, except where main dwelling is permitted to extend into rear yard.

conditions.text: Basements (even habitable ones) do not count as floor area if first floor is no more than 3' above grade.
Excavation will not affect grade or measurement of floor area if standards are met.
Excavated features meet size/dimensional limits described in Figs 39-40 on pp. 42-43.
Excavated features exceed size/dimensional limits described in Figs 39-40 on pp. 42-43.

logical_relationships.expression: If excavated features meet size/dimensional limits described in Figs 39-40 on pp. 42-43, then grade is measured as shown by 'A' in Fig 36.
If excavated features exceed size/dimensional limits described in Figs 39-40 on pp. 42-43, then grade is measured as shown by 'B' in Fig 36.

execution_sequence.action: Verify basement location and encroachment conditions (q1, q2, q3).
Determine if basement floor area counts based on first floor height above grade.
Evaluate excavated features against size/dimensional limits to determine applicable grade measurement.
Apply FAR rules for excavation if standards are met.
